choices.text: It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tubercular osteomyelitis is not true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Periosteal reaction is characteristic

 

Periosteal reaction is not characteristic of tubercular osteomyelitis. In fact, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents as a well-defined area of bone destruction with minimal reactive new bone formation. This is distinctly different from pyogenic osteomyelitis where significant periosteal new bone formation is an important feature. The only exception is "Spina Ventosa" (tubercular dactylitis) where periosteal reaction can be seen in the digits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis is always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body, commonly in the lungs or lymph nodes. The infection spreads to bone hematogenously.

 

Option B. Sequestrum is uncommon - This is actually true for typical tubercular osteomyelitis. While sequestra can occur, they are less common and less prominent compared to pyogenic osteomyelitis due to the more indolent nature of the infection.

 

Option D. Inflammation is minimal - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis causes a chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than the acute suppurative inflammation seen in pyogenic infections. The lesions are paucibacillary (containing few bacteria) with minimal inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unlike pyogenic osteomyelitis, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents with well-defined bone destruction, minimal periosteal reaction, less prominent sequestrum formation, and chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than acute suppurative changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a trinucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontotemporal Dementia

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders are a group of genetic conditions caused by the repetition of a specific set of three nucleotides within certain genes. These repeats can expand during DNA replication, leading to various diseases depending on the gene affected.

 

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) is generally not associated with trinucleotide repeat expansions. While some familial cases of FTD may be linked to mutations, such as hexanucleotide repeat expansions (six nucleotide repeats) in certain genes, it is not considered a trinucleotide repeat disorder like the other options provided.

 

Note –

 

Hexanucleotide repeat disorders:

 

  • One subtype of familial FTD (Frontotemporal Dementia) is being associated with hexanucleotide repeat expansions (c8 or c9 repeats)
  • Pick's disease (a variant of Frontotemporal Dementia), characterized by specific pathological findings such as Pick cells and sharp, knife-edge gyri.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) can be linked to hexanucleotide repeat expansions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fragile X syndrome: This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option B. Huntington Chorea: Also known as Huntington's disease, it is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeats in the HTT gene. This primarily affects the caudate nucleus of the brain. It is associated with decreased levels of neurotransmitters like acetylcholine and GABA.

 

Option D. Myotonic dystrophy: This condition is due to a CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene. Features include the development of Christmas tree cataracts, gonadal atrophy, and early onset alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontotemporal Dementia is not classified as a trinucleotide repeat disorder, distinguishing it from conditions like Fragile X syndrome, Huntington's disease, and Myotonic dystrophy, which are directly caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, and bilateral cataracts. The mother reports a febrile illness during the first trimester of pregnancy. Imaging reveals intracranial calcifications. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests congenital toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  • Hydrocephalus
  • Intracranial calcifications
  • Chorioretinitis/cataracts

 

The history of maternal febrile illness during the first trimester is significant, as this is when the fetus is most vulnerable to congenital infections. T. gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that can cross the placenta and cause severe damage to the developing fetal nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): While CMV can cause congenital infections, its classic presentation includes microcephaly rather than hydrocephalus, and hepatosplenomegaly is more common.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Typically presents with vesicular skin lesions and encephalitis in neonates. Transmission usually occurs during delivery rather than in the first trimester.

 

Option D. Rubella virus: Though it can cause congenital defects, its classic triad includes cataracts, deafness, and cardiac defects (particularly patent ductus arteriosus).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis: hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis/cataracts.

choices.text: Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance
Stria albicans – Cushing syndrome
Xeroderma pigmentosum – Freckles
Café au lait spots – McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: An overweight 13-year-old girl has the following blackish discoloration on her neck, as shown in the image below. What is this condition and its association? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance

 

Option A.

 

Acanthosis Nigricans:

 

  • This condition is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically found in the intertriginous areas such as the neck, axilla, and groin.
  • The lesion’s appearance in the image is consistent with Acanthosis Nigricans.
  • It is commonly associated with insulin resistance and can be a marker for type 2 diabetes mellitus, especially in the context of overweight or obesity, as seen in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Striae Albicans:

 

  • This refers to the white or silver stretch marks that occur when the skin has been stretched rapidly as in the case of rapid weight gain or with conditions like Cushing syndrome.

 

 

  • However, the image does not show stretch marks but rather a hyperpigmented, thickened area of skin.

 

Option C. Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

 

 

  • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

 

Option D. Café au lait spots:

 

  • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome.

 

 

  • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Acanthosis Nigricans by its velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the neck and its association with insulin resistance in the context of obesity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

PCSK-9 inhibitors are a class of drugs that significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels by inhibiting the protein PCSK-9, which in turn increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood.

 

There are only 2 PCSK-9 inhibitors: Evolocumab and alirocumab. Among the options provided:

 

Evolocumab is a well-known PCSK-9 inhibitor used in modern clinical practice to manage hyperlipidemia, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is an NPC1L1 transport inhibitor, also known as an intestinal cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It reduces blood cholesterol by decreasing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a newer drug that acts as an ANGPTL3 inhibitor. It is specifically approved for use in patients with familial homozygous type 2 hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and an immunosuppressive drug used primarily in organ transplantation and certain types of cancer. It is not related to the treatment of dyslipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

 

After one week liquefaction occurs, so the body undergoes significant decomposition. General recognition is not helpful due to the gross distortion of the body. Dental records are also not useful because teeth typically fall out within three to five days post-mortem. Fingerprints can be compromised as the skin begins to degrade, with degloving of the skin occurring within three to five days and complete skin decomposition taking up to one month. However, DNA profiling remains a reliable method even in advanced decomposition, as DNA can be extracted from bones and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General recognition: This is ineffective after a week of decomposition due to the significant distortion and liquefaction of the body.

 

Option C. Dental records: Teeth fall out within three to five days after death, making dental records unreliable for identification after one week.

 

Option D. Finger prints: The skin undergoes degloving within three to five days and further decomposition, making fingerprinting unreliable. Additionally, without a criminal background, there would be no pre-existing fingerprint records for comparison.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous involvement of the gut

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but they have distinct pathological and clinical features.

 

Key Features of Crohn's Disease:

 

  • Segmental involvement: Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, segmental involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, known as "skip lesions." This contrasts with ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous, uninterrupted inflammation of the colon.

 

Continuous Involvement of the Gut:

 

This feature is typical of ulcerative colitis, where the inflammation is continuous and starts from the rectum extending proximally in a continuous manner without skipping any areas. In Crohn's disease, the inflammation is discontinuous, with normal areas interspersed between inflamed regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of colon cancer: This is true for Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, as the risk of progression to malignancy is generally lower, especially for non-colonic Crohn's.

 

Option C. Higher risk of perianal fistula: Crohn's disease has a higher risk of perianal complications, including fistulas, due to the transmural nature of its inflammation.

 

Option D. Rarely present with daily hematochezia: Daily hematochezia is less common in Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, which is more likely to cause continuous bloody diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

 

Key Differences Between Crohn’s Disease & Ulcerative Colitis:

questions.text: The third ventricle is the cavity of which part of the brain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Diencephalon

 

The third ventricle is the cavity of the diencephalon, which is part of the forebrain (prosencephalon). The diencephalon consists of thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus, metathalamus, and subthalamus. The third ventricle is a narrow cavity that lies between the two halves of the thalamus. It communicates with the lateral ventricles through the interventricular foramina of Monro, and posteriorly it continues as the cerebral aqueduct which passes through the midbrain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Telencephalon - The telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) contains the lateral ventricles, not the third ventricle. The lateral ventricles are C-shaped cavities within each cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Mesencephalon - The mesencephalon (midbrain) contains the cerebral aqueduct (aqueduct of Sylvius), not the third ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle.

 

Option C. Rhombencephalon - The rhombencephalon (hindbrain) contains the fourth ventricle, not the third ventricle. The fourth ventricle is the cavity of the pons, medulla oblongata and cerebellum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The third ventricle is specifically the cavity of the diencephalon, situated between the two thalami, and forms part of the ventricular system connecting the lateral ventricles to the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: Which nerve provides the motor and sensory supply to the diaphragm? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Phrenic nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The phrenic nerve provides both motor and sensory innervation to the diaphragm. It arises from the cervical plexus, specifically from C3-C5 spinal nerve roots (predominantly C4). The phrenic nerve descends through the neck, enters the thorax, and runs between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura to reach the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve is shorter, more vertical, and passes through the vena caval opening of the diaphragm, while the left phrenic nerve is longer, more oblique, and pierces the left cupola of the diaphragm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2, C3, C4 Roots: While the phrenic nerve does originate from cervical roots (mainly C3-C5, with C4 predominating), these roots themselves do not directly supply the diaphragm. They contribute to forming the phrenic nerve, which then innervates the diaphragm.

 

Option C. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve (C6, C7, C8) supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle, not the diaphragm. It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve (C5, C6, C7) supplies the serratus anterior muscle, not the diaphragm. It's an important nerve for scapular stabilization during arm movements.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The phrenic nerve (C3-C5) is the sole motor and sensory nerve of the diaphragm, with irritation of its central portion causing referred pain to the shoulder tip due to shared C4 innervation.

choices.text: Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2 presents with delayed menstrual cycles, mild abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the ultrasound features suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

 

In ectopic pregnancy, transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation. The most characteristic finding is an empty uterine cavity with a mass in the adnexa  and fluid collection in the pelvis. The fluid represents blood from either tubal abortion or rupture, which typically collects in the pouch of Douglas behind the uterus. These findings together strongly suggest an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass: Incorrect because in ectopic pregnancy, the presence of an adnexal mass is a key diagnostic feature. Without an adnexal mass, the diagnosis is incomplete.

 

Option C. Intra uterine gestational sac: Incorrect as this finding indicates a normal intrauterine pregnancy, not an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Thick endometrium: Incorrect because this finding alone is nonspecific and can be seen in various conditions. It does not help diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classic ultrasound findings in ectopic pregnancy are:

 

1. Empty uterine cavity

 

2. Adnexal mass (Bagel sign/ Blob sign)

 

3. Gestational sac with yolk sav/ fetal pole in the adnexa

 

4. Ring of fire on Doppler

 

 

5. Free fluid in the pelvis (representing blood from abortion or rupture)

questions.text: Heat-producing Mechanisms are initiated in which part of the hypothalamus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Posterior hypothalamus

 

Explanation: 

 

The posterior hypothalamus is the primary site responsible for initiating heat-producing (thermogenic) Mechanisms in response to cold stimuli. When body temperature drops below normal, the posterior hypothalamus triggers various mechanisms to increase heat production and decrease heat loss, maintaining body temperature within the normal range.

 

Evidence from Sources

 

  • Posterior hypothalamic stimulation causes shivering - a key heat-generating mechanism
  • Animals with posterior hypothalamic lesions experience body temperature drop toward environmental temperature
  • The threshold for activating responses like nonshivering thermogenesis (36°C) and shivering (35.5°C) are controlled by posterior hypothalamic centers
  • Stimulation of this region increases sympathetic outflow, leading to increased metabolic rate and heat production

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Anterior hypothalamus - This region is primarily involved in heat-dissipating mechanisms, not heat production. Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, which promotes heat loss rather than heat production.
  • Option C. Lateral hypothalamus - While this region has important functions related to hunger and food intake, it's not specifically identified as the primary controller of heat-producing reflexes in response to cold. The lateral hypothalamic nucleus is mentioned in relation to sympathetic responses but not as the main thermogenic center.
  • Option D. Arcuate nucleus - This region is primarily involved in neuroendocrine functions, particularly housing dopamine-secreting neurons that regulate prolactin and growth hormone-releasing neurons. It's not identified as a primary thermoregulatory center for heat production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior hypothalamus functions as the body's central thermostat for responses to cold, initiating heat-conservation mechanisms (vasoconstriction) and heat-generating reflexes (shivering, increased metabolism) when body temperature falls below normal levels.

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low BP and elevated JVP. What is the likely JVP finding? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent y descent

 

The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds, low blood pressure, and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the JVP is elevated, and the typical waveform finding is a prominent x descent with a blunted or diminished y descent. This pattern is due to the restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle during diastole because of the pressure exerted by the pericardial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent a wave: This is seen in patients with atrial fibrillation, where there is no organized atrial contraction.

 

Option C. Prominent y descent: This is seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, where there is a rapid early diastolic filling, known as Friedrich's sign.

 

Option D. Absent x descent: This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation, where the backward flow of blood during systole reduces the x descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the JVP waveform shows a prominent x descent with an absent or blunted y descent. This is due to the restricted filling of the right heart chambers caused by the pericardial fluid, leading to characteristic clinical signs such as muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

 

The abdominal X-ray KUB image shows a stent, specifically a double J (DJ) stent, commonly used in surgeries. The appearance and orientation of the stent are key to identifying its location. In this case, the stent is positioned vertically, which indicates it is in the bile duct. The bile duct runs vertically in the body, and a biliary stent used in procedures like ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) would also be oriented vertically. Conversely, a stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally due to the anatomical layout of the pancreatic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP and Pancreatic duct: A stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally, not vertically, due to the horizontal course of the pancreatic duct. The given image shows a vertically oriented stent, which rules out this option.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic balloon catheter: This type of catheter would have a different appearance and is not typically placed in a vertical orientation like the stent shown in the X-ray.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous catheter: This type of catheter is used for different purposes and would not appear as a vertical stent in the abdominal X-ray. It also wouldn't be located in the bile duct or pancreatic duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: 40-year-old male was started on tuberculosis treatment after which he started complaining of visual disturbances. Which drug is likely to cause this side effect? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is a first-line antituberculosis medication that is known to cause visual disturbances as a side effect. The most common visual side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, which can present with symptoms such as decreased visual acuity, color blindness, and visual field defects. These symptoms are due to the toxic effects of ethambutol on the optic nerve. It is important for patients on ethambutol to have regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for early signs of optic neuritis, which can be reversible if the drug is discontinued promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: While isoniazid can cause peripheral neuropathy and, less commonly, optic neuritis, it is not the most common cause of visual disturbances among the antituberculosis drugs.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is known for causing a red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids and potential hepatotoxicity, but it is not commonly associated with visual disturbances.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is associated with hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia leading to gout, but it is not known to cause visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the antituberculosis drug most commonly associated with visual disturbances, particularly optic neuritis.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

choices.text: By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

 

Explanation:

 

PTH increases calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing the kidneys' excretion of calcium, effectively increasing plasma calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By increasing osteoclast activity: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclasts indirectly, leading to increased bone resorption, which releases calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. By increasing osteoblastic activity: While PTH does stimulate osteoblasts, this action is primarily to produce RANKL, a cytokine that activates osteoclasts, not to build new bone.

 

Option C. By decreasing renal excretion: PTH reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys, increasing reabsorption of calcium in the renal tubules, contributing to higher blood calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases plasma calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing renal excretion of calcium.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence 

 

The incident described in the scenario will be tried under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence refers to a disregard for the safety of others that is so gross or extreme that it constitutes a criminal act.

 

Even in emergency, the surgeon should not have performed operation while under the influence of alcohol.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence: In this there is no specific and clear violation of law. Simple absence of care and skill. The trial is conducted in a civil court and typically results in fine as punishment. The negligence described in the scenario is too gross to be considered merely civil negligence.

 

Option C. Therapeutic Misadventure (Medical Maloccurence): Individual is injured or died due to some unintentional Act by a doctor/hospital and is not related to the quality of care provided. It is an unforeseen accident due to individual biological variations. Here no one is negligent.

 

Option D. Dichotomy or Fee Splitting or Sharing: Giving of a commission  by  one  doctor  to  another  for  referring, recommending, or procuring any patients for medical, surgical or other treatment. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by State Medical Council. The punishment can be:

 

  • Warning
  • Penal erasure (professional death sentence).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text: A person presents to the clinic with normal eye closure and intact facial wrinkles but paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. Which structure is most likely involved in this case? ((FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) left CN 7 supranuclear lesion 

 

The presentation describes a supranuclear (upper motor neuron) lesion of the facial nerve on the right side. 

 

In supranuclear lesions of CN7

 

  • The upper facial muscles (for eye closure and forehead wrinkles) receive bilateral cortical innervation, so they are spared in supranuclear lesions  
  • The lower facial muscles receive only contralateral cortical innervation 
  • Due to decussation of nerve fibers, a left supranuclear lesion causes right-sided lower facial weakness
    • Since the right lower face is paralyzed, the lesion must be in the left corticobulbar tract, making the correct answer "Left CN 7 Supranuclear lesion" 

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Left CN 7 Infranuclear lesion: Incorrect because infranuclear (lower motor neuron) lesions cause complete ipsilateral facial paralysis affecting both upper and lower face.

 

Option B. Right CN 7 Supranuclear lesion: Incorrect because a right supranuclear lesion would cause left sided lower facial weakness due to decussation of fibers.

 

Option D. Right CN 7 Infranuclear lesion: Incorrect because infranuclear lesions cause complete facial paralysis on the same side, including forehead and eye closure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  1. Supranuclear lesions: Preserve forehead wrinkles and eye closure but affect contralateral lower face
  2. Infranuclear lesions: Cause complete ipsilateral facial paralysis affecting both upper and lower face

questions.text: The inferior epigastric artery originates from which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. External iliac artery

 

The inferior epigastric artery originates from the external iliac artery just above the inguinal ligament near the lower end. It runs upwards and medially in the extraperitoneal connective tissue, passes just medial to the deep inguinal ring, pierces the fascia transversalis at the lateral border of the rectus abdominis, and enters the rectus sheath by passing in front of the arcuate line. Within the sheath, it supplies the rectus muscle and ends by anastomosing with the superior epigastric artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Internal iliac artery - This artery gives rise to branches that supply pelvic viscera and the gluteal region, but it does not give rise to the inferior epigastric artery. The internal iliac artery provides branches like the superior and inferior gluteal arteries, internal pudendal artery, and obturator artery.

 

Option C. Femoral artery - The femoral artery is the continuation of the external iliac artery below the inguinal ligament. It supplies the lower limb and gives branches like the superficial epigastric artery (not the inferior epigastric), but not the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Option D. Thoracic artery - The thoracic artery (likely referring to the internal thoracic/internal mammary artery) gives rise to the superior epigastric artery, not the inferior epigastric. The superior epigastric artery anastomoses with the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The inferior epigastric artery is a branch of the external iliac artery that runs upward in the anterior abdominal wall to supply the rectus abdominis muscle and forms an important anastomosis with the superior epigastric artery, creating a connection between the subclavian and external iliac arterial systems.

questions.text: Which type of nerve fibers has the slowest conduction velocity? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. C fibers

 

Explanation: 

 

C fibers have the slowest conduction velocity among all nerve fiber types, ranging from 0.5-2 m/s. These are thin unmyelinated fibers that primarily carry slow pain and temperature sensations and include postganglionic autonomic nerves. The conduction velocities of different nerve fibers are arranged in descending order as follows: Aα (70-120 m/s) > Aβ (30-70 m/s) > Aγ (15-30 m/s) > Aδ (12-30 m/s) > B (3-7 m/s) > C (0.5-2 m/s).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Aα fibers: These are thick myelinated fibers carrying motor and proprioception signals with conduction velocities of 70-120 m/s, making them the fastest conducting fibers.
  • Option B. Aβ fibers: These myelinated fibers conduct at 30-70 m/s and carry sensations of pressure, vibration, touch, and stereognosis.
  • Option C. B fibers: These thin myelinated preganglionic autonomic nerve fibers conduct at 3-7 m/s, which is slow but still faster than C fibers.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conduction velocity is directly proportional to fiber diameter and myelination; therefore, C fibers being thin and unmyelinated have the slowest conduction velocity (0.5-2 m/s).

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

 

The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the rapid onset of painful urethral discharge are highly indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal urethritis typically presents with dysuria (painful urination) and a purulent (pus-like) discharge from the urethra.

 

The treatment of choice for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This treatment is preferred due to its efficacy in eradicating the infection and its convenience as a single-dose therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 2 weeks: Doxycycline is typically used for treating chlamydial infections, which can co-occur with gonorrhea but is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea itself. Additionally, a two-week course is usually prescribed for chlamydia, not gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Benzathine Penicillin: Benzathine Penicillin is primarily used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhea. Syphilis and gonorrhea are different sexually transmitted infections with distinct treatments.

 

Option D. Azithromycin 1 gm stat: Azithromycin can be used in the treatment of chlamydial infections, often alongside treatment for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection. However, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea when given alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A patient having hypertension, is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can prevent potassium loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amiloride

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide, chlorthalidone, and metolazone, are known for causing potassium wasting, which can result in hypokalemia and associated symptoms like fatigue. To counteract this effect, potassium-sparing diuretics can be used.

 

Amiloride is an epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitor, which is a type of potassium-sparing diuretic. It helps prevent potassium loss by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules of the kidneys, thereby reducing potassium excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and is not suitable for preventing potassium loss.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic, which is not typically used for potassium conservation and can also cause electrolyte imbalances.

 

Option D. Indapamide: This is another thiazide-like diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and does not prevent potassium loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to prevent potassium loss in patients on thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: A 80 year old male presented with diminution of vision since 2 years. The right eye was red and painful. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg in right eye and 16 mmHg in left eye. The right eye had deep anterior chamber with some cells and flare. What could be the possibility? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

 

Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by the leakage of lens proteins through an intact lens capsule, which causes an inflammatory response in the eye. This condition often occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts. The leakage of proteins results in cells and flare in the anterior chamber, as well as a deep anterior chamber. The clinical presentation described in the question, including the deep anterior chamber with cells and flare and the patient's age, aligns with the characteristics of phacolytic glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: Malignant glaucoma, also known as aqueous misdirection syndrome, is characterized by a shallow anterior chamber and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition typically does not present with cells and flare in the anterior chamber, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis usually presents in younger patients, and it is less likely to occur in an 80-year-old individual. This condition is characterized by heterochromia (difference in eye color) and mild anterior uveitis, but it does not typically present with the deep anterior chamber and the level of inflammation described in the question.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma occurs due to the swelling of a mature cataract, which leads to a shallow anterior chamber and increased IOP. The question describes a deep anterior chamber, which is not consistent with phacomorphic glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phacolytic glaucoma presents with a deep anterior chamber, cells and flare due to leakage of lens proteins, and typically occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts.

choices.text: Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with blurred vision, dry mouth, and progressive muscle weakness after consuming improperly canned food. The symptoms are attributed to a neurotoxin. What is the mechanism of action of Clostridium botulinum toxin? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction


Clostridium botulinum produces a potent neurotoxin that specifically blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage prevents muscle contraction, resulting in flaccid paralysis. The classic symptoms include blurred vision, dry mouth, and descending muscle weakness due to the toxin's effect on cholinergic synapses.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inhibits acetylcholine receptors: The toxin does not inhibit receptors but blocks neurotransmitter release. 

 

Option B. Inhibits GABA release: Botulinum toxin specifically affects acetylcholine, not GABA.

 

Option D. Increases EF-2 activity: This is not the mechanism of botulinum toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (-2D in right eye and +1D in left eye) in a 6-year-old child with normal visual acuity and retinal findings on fundus examination, is suggestive of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anisometropia

 

Explanation:

 

Anisometropia refers to a significant difference in refractive power between the two eyes. In this case:

 

  • The right eye has myopia (-2D).
  • The left eye has hypermetropia (+1D).
  • This meets the criteria for anisometropia, which is defined as a difference of at least 2.5 diopters between the two eyes.
  • A difference in refractive errors between both eyes leads to different image sizes (anisokonia).
  • If untreated, the brain may suppress the image from one eye, potentially leading to anisometropic amblyopia.
  • It can be corrected using glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mixed Astigmatism:

 

  • In mixed astigmatism, both myopia and hypermetropia occur within the same eye, affecting different meridians.
  • This patient has different refractive errors in each eye, not within the same eye.

 

Option C. Myopia:

 

  • Myopia (near-sightedness) occurs when light focuses in front of the retina, causing blurred distance vision.
  • Since the left eye is hypermetropic, this case is not pure myopia.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia:

 

  • Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) occurs when light focuses behind the retina, making near vision more difficult.
  • Since the right eye is myopic, the child does not have bilateral hypermetropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is a condition where the two eyes have significantly different refractive errors, which can lead to amblyopia if untreated. Early correction with spectacles or contact lenses is essential to prevent visual impairment.

choices.text: Fracture of the head of radius

questions.text: Nursemaid’s Elbow refers to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Subluxation of proximal radioulnar joint

 

Nursemaid's Elbow refers to a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint where the annular ligament partially slips over the radial head. This typically occurs in young children (ages 1-4) when the arm is suddenly pulled longitudinally, such as when an adult pulls a child's hand to prevent falling or to lift them. The partial displacement of the annular ligament causes pain and the child typically holds the arm in pronation with the elbow slightly flexed, refusing to use it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow is not a complete dislocation of the elbow joint but rather a subluxation specifically of the proximal radioulnar joint where the radius and ulna meet at the elbow.

 

Option B: This is incorrect. Subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint typically occurs from a fall on an outstretched hand and affects the wrist area, not the elbow. This is not Nursemaid's Elbow.

 

Option D: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow does not involve a fracture of the radial head. It is a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament rather than a bony injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nursemaid's Elbow (radial head subluxation) is a common pediatric injury involving slippage of the annular ligament over the radial head at the proximal radioulnar joint, typically caused by longitudinal traction to the arm and treated with simple reduction maneuvers.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: How does the Bohr effect operate in myoglobin compared to hemoglobin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. No Bohr effect

 

Explanation:


The Bohr effect refers to the decreased oxygen affinity of hemoglobin when pH falls or PCO₂ rises. This effect occurs because deoxygenated hemoglobin binds H⁺ more actively than oxygenated hemoglobin. The Bohr effect is dependent on hemoglobin's quaternary structure and cooperative binding between its four subunits.

 

Myoglobin, in contrast, has fundamentally different structural and functional properties:

 

  • Contains only one heme group versus hemoglobin's four
  • Exhibits no cooperative binding (rectangular hyperbola curve versus sigmoid)
  • Has higher oxygen affinity than hemoglobin (leftward shifted curve)
  • Lacks the quaternary structure needed for the Bohr effect

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increased - Incorrect because myoglobin cannot have an increased Bohr effect when it lacks the structural basis for this effect entirely.
  • Option b. Decreased - Incorrect because "decreased" would suggest myoglobin still exhibits some Bohr effect, just to a lesser degree than hemoglobin.
  • Option c. Same - Incorrect because myoglobin's structure (single oxygen-binding site) fundamentally prevents it from exhibiting the same pH-dependent oxygen affinity changes seen in hemoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bohr effect requires a quaternary protein structure with cooperative binding properties as found in hemoglobin; myoglobin's monomeric structure with a single oxygen-binding site prevents it from exhibiting this physiologically important effect.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, should be stopped on the day of surgery because:

 

  • ACE inhibitors can cause refractory hypotension during surgery
  • This hypotension is resistant to fluid therapy and vasopressors
  • It occurs when the medication is taken within hours before surgery
  • The recommendation is to omit ACE inhibitors and ARBs on the morning of surgery


Other Options:

 

Options A & D. Aspirin: If taken in a prophylactic dose of 75 mg, it can be continued on the day of surgery. However, if taken in higher doses (150-300 mg), it increases the risk of surgical bleeding and should be stopped 3 days before surgery.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are safe to continue as they help maintain stable hemodynamics during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.

 

Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives 

 

  1. ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  2. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  3. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. 
  4. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  5. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  6. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery. 

 

ANTICOAGULANTS 

 

  • Aspirin continued on day of surgery 
  • Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery 
  • Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery 
  • Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery 
  • LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery 
  • Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery 
  • BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: In the diagnosis of Visceral Leishmaniasis, from which organ is the diagnostic yield the highest? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Spleen 

 

Explanation: 

 

Splenic aspiration provides the highest diagnostic yield for visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), with a sensitivity of 93-99%. The spleen contains the highest concentration of Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies or amastigotes), making it the most reliable site for parasite detection. The amastigotes can be visualized microscopically in splenic aspirate smears stained with Giemsa or Leishman stains. Despite its high sensitivity, splenic aspiration carries a risk of serious hemorrhage (0.1%) and is usually performed only in specialized centers with surgical backup.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Liver - Incorrect. While liver biopsy can be used for diagnosis, the sensitivity is lower (approximately 75-85%) compared to splenic aspiration. Additionally, liver biopsy carries risks of bleeding and bile leak.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspirate - Incorrect. Bone marrow aspiration has lower sensitivity (60-85%) compared to splenic aspiration but is more commonly performed due to its relatively lower risk profile. It is often the first invasive diagnostic test performed.

 

Option D. Lymph nodes - Incorrect. Lymph node aspiration has the lowest sensitivity (50-60%) among these options for diagnosing visceral leishmaniasis. It is useful primarily in patients with significant lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenic aspiration provides the highest diagnostic yield for visceral leishmaniasis, but due to risk of hemorrhage, bone marrow aspiration is often performed first, with splenic aspiration reserved for cases where other methods have failed to provide a diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the function of secretin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Delays gastric emptying

 

Explanation:


Secretin is a hormone produced by S cells in the duodenum in response to acid. Secretin works in conjunction with CCK-PZ, enhancing its action through a positive correlation. Since CCK-PZ inhibits gastric emptying by acting on the pylorus, secretin indirectly delays gastric emptying through this enhancement of CCK-PZ action.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Antagonizes the action of CCK - This is incorrect because secretin promotes rather than antagonizes CCK action. The relationship between secretin and CCK-PZ shows enhancement, not antagonism.
  • Option B. Stimulates gastrin secretion - This is incorrect because secretin inhibits gastrin secretion, which leads to reduced acid secretion. Secretin and gastrin have an inverse relationship in the regulation of gastric acid.
  • Option D. All of the above - Since options A and B are incorrect, "All of the above" cannot be correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretin delays gastric emptying by enhancing the action of CCK-PZ, which inhibits the pyloric sphincter. Additionally, secretin stimulates bicarbonate-rich pancreatic secretions and inhibits gastrin secretion, contributing to its role in coordinating digestive processes.

questions.text: Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. In the proximal calf

 

Explanation:

 

Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located in the proximal calf region. It is one of the important named perforator veins that forms a direct communication between the superficial and deep venous systems. Specifically, Boyd's perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the deep veins (posterior tibial vein) at the level of the proximal calf. This perforator is clinically significant in patients with chronic venous insufficiency as incompetence in this perforator can contribute to varicose veins and venous hypertension.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. In the proximal thigh: This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's.
  • Option B. In the distal thigh: Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location.
  • Option D. In the distal calf: This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Boyd's perforator is located in the proximal calf, serving as an important communication between the great saphenous vein and deep posterior tibial vein. Its incompetence plays a significant role in the development of venous hypertension and varicose veins.

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not considered a core risk factor group for HIV transmission? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-distance truck drivers

 

The core risk groups for HIV transmission are populations that primarily transmit the disease to bridge populations, who then transmit it to the general population. In endemic countries like India, addressing these core groups is crucial for reducing HIV transmission rates. The core high-risk groups include female sex workers, men who have sex with men (MSM), transgender populations, and injectable drug users.

 

Long-distance truck drivers are considered a bridge population rather than a core risk group. While they are important in the transmission chain, they act as intermediaries between core risk groups and the general population.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Female sex workers: Incorrect. This is a core risk group according to NACO 2024 data and is one of the primary populations targeted for HIV prevention.

 

Option C. Male having sex with male (MSM): Incorrect. MSM is a core high-risk group that requires focused intervention for HIV prevention.

 

Option D. IV drug abusers: Incorrect. Injectable drug users are considered a core high-risk group for HIV transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinction between core risk groups and bridge populations in HIV transmission:

 

Core risk groups include:

 

  1. Female sex workers
  2. Men who have sex with men (MSM)
  3. Transgender populations
  4. Injectable drug users

 

Bridge populations, like truck drivers and migrants, serve as intermediaries in disease transmission.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The patient is dehydrated and the blood pressure of the patient is 90/60 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations revealed the serum potassium level of 6.0 mEq/L, sodium level of 129 mEq/L, and blood glucose level of 40 mg/dL. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for which he was prescribed medication by a local physician; however, the patient abruptly discontinued the medication a few weeks ago. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following drugs should be administered as a life-saving measure to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrocortisone

 

Hydrocortisone is indicated as it would treat adrenal insufficiency. It would help to correct hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia by replacing the deficient cortisol.

 

The clinical presentation of hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia in a patient who has suddenly stopped taking medication for RA (potentially a corticosteroid) suggests the possibility of adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis. This is particularly likely if the medication the patient was taking for RA was a corticosteroid, which is common in the management of RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis, which is not indicated in this case as there is no mention of acidosis in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin is used in the treatment of hyperkalemia to drive potassium into cells, but it would not address the underlying adrenal insufficiency and could potentially worsen the hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Hypertonic saline: Hypertonic saline is used to treat severe hyponatremia, which is not present in this case, as the sodium level is within normal limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the drug of choice for treating adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis, which can present with hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia, especially in patients with a history of corticosteroid use who abruptly discontinue their medication.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' orbitopathy, is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals. TED is an autoimmune condition associated with thyroid dysfunction, typically hyperthyroidism. The disease leads to inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, causing the eyes to bulge outward (proptosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital varix: Orbital varices are venous malformations that can cause intermittent proptosis, but they are not the most common cause. They typically become symptomatic during activities that increase venous pressure, such as straining or bending over.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant intraocular tumor that primarily affects children. It is not a common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors and the most common orbital tumor in adults, but they are not the most frequent cause of proptosis. These tumors tend to grow slowly and cause progressive proptosis.

 

Intraocular tumours

Most common in adults : Melanoma

Most common in children : Retinoblastoma

 

Intraorbital tumours

Most common in adults : Hemangioma

Most common in children : Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

 

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) typically leads to asymmetric leg swelling, where one leg is more affected than the other. In cases of CVI, the swelling is often unilateral, and if bilateral, it is usually asymmetric. This makes it the least common cause of bipedal (symmetric) edema among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Nephritis: This condition affects the kidneys, leading to fluid retention and typically causing bilateral leg swelling. It is a common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: This systemic condition causes the heart to pump blood inefficiently, leading to fluid buildup in the lower extremities and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic Liver Disease: This condition results in decreased protein synthesis and portal hypertension, causing fluid retention and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a confirmed diagnosis of mild to moderate Alzheimer's dementia has shown aversion and non-compliance to oral medications. The patient's caregiver reports difficulty in administering the oral drugs due to the patient's refusal to swallow pills. Considering the need for continued treatment, which of the following medications could be prescribed in a form that does not require oral administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rivastigmine

 

Rivastigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of mild to moderate dementia in Alzheimer's disease. Unlike memantine, donepezil, and galantamine, rivastigmine has the advantage of being available in a transdermal patch form. The transdermal patch allows for continuous delivery of the medication through the skin, which is beneficial for patients who are non-compliant with oral medications or have difficulty swallowing pills.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Memantine: Memantine is used in moderate to severe dementia and is usually administered orally. To date, there is no alternative route of administration available for memantine.

 

Option B. Donepezil: Donepezil is typically administered orally and is used in all stages of Alzheimer's disease. There is an orally disintegrating tablet form, but it still requires the ability to manage oral intake.

 

Option D. Galantamine: Galantamine is also used for mild to moderate Alzheimer's dementia and is administered orally. There is no non-oral formulation available for galantamine.

 

In conclusion, for a patient who refuses oral medication, rivastigmine can be prescribed in a patch form, providing an alternative route of administration that ensures the patient can continue to receive their dementia management therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with Alzheimer's dementia who refuses oral medication, rivastigmine can be prescribed in a transdermal patch form, providing an alternative route of administration that ensures the patient can continue to receive their dementia management therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Phenylketonuria (PKU) is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Excess Melanin

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is characterized by decreased melanin, not excess melanin. PKU is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. This deficiency leads to increased levels of phenylalanine in the blood and decreased levels of tyrosine. Since tyrosine is a precursor for melanin synthesis, patients with PKU have decreased melanin production, resulting in characteristic physical features including blonde hair, fair skin, and blue eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficient Tyrosine - This is actually correct. In PKU, the body cannot convert phenylalanine to tyrosine due to the enzyme deficiency, resulting in decreased tyrosine levels.

 

Option B. Excess Phenylalanine - This is correct. PKU results in elevated levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate) due to the enzymatic defect.

 

Option D. Autosomal Recessive - This is correct. PKU follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, requiring mutations in both copies of the phenylalanine hydroxylase gene.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phenylketonuria results in decreased (not increased) melanin production, leading to characteristic features like fair skin, blonde hair and blue eyes due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis.

questions.text: The Ripstein procedure is done for: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Rectal prolapse

 

Explanation:

 

The Ripstein procedure is a type of abdominal rectopexy used specifically for treating full-thickness rectal prolapse. It involves placing a mesh anterior to the rectum like a sling and fixing it to the sacrum behind. This technique suspends the rectum and prevents prolapse, though it has more post-operative complications due to its sling effect compared to other rectopexy methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirschsprung disease - This is treated with pull-through procedures (Swenson, Duhamel, or Soave) which resect the aganglionic segment and create a colo-anal anastomosis, not with rectopexy.

 

Option C. Hemorrhoids - These are treated with different procedures including banding, sclerotherapy, hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan or Ferguson), stapled hemorrhoidopexy, or newer techniques like Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - This condition requires Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy, which involves cutting the pyloric muscle along its length while preserving the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein rectopexy uses a mesh sling placed anterior to the rectum for full-thickness rectal prolapse, but has higher post-operative constipation rates compared to other rectopexy techniques like Well's procedure.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

questions.text: A person has suffered from chest trauma resulting in fracture of 2-6th ribs. He is being given pain relief by IV analgesic agents. Which of these blocks will be helpful in pain relief? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic epidural

 

For multiple rib fractures (2nd-6th ribs), thoracic epidural is the most appropriate choice  because:

 

  • It provides effective pain relief by blocking multiple spinal nerve roots at once through a single catheter
  • The epidural can be placed at T4-T5 level to cover the affected dermatomes
  • It allows continuous analgesia through catheter placement
  • It provides stable hemodynamics
  • The epidural catheter can be used for repeated administration of local anesthetic for prolonged pain relief

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical plexus block: Only supplies the neck and shoulder region. Not suitable for rib fractures as it does not cover the thoracic dermatomes.

 

Option B. Supraclavicular block: This is a brachial plexus block that provides anesthesia to the upper limb. It does not cover the thoracic area or ribs.

 

Option D. Lumbar epidural: Provides analgesia below the umbilicus. Not suitable for upper thoracic dermatomes where the fractured ribs are located.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thoracic epidural is the optimal choice for pain management in multiple rib fractures as it provides effective analgesia through continuous blockade of multiple thoracic dermatomes.

questions.text: What is the renal threshold for serum glucose level? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 200 mg/dL

 

Explanation:


The renal threshold for glucose is the plasma level at which glucose first appears in the urine in more than normal minute amounts. This threshold is approximately 200 mg/dL in arterial plasma, corresponding to about 180 mg/dL in venous blood. At this concentration, the glucose filtered through the glomeruli begins to exceed the maximum tubular reabsorptive capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option 100 mg/dL: This value is too low. Normal plasma glucose ranges around 80-100 mg/dL, and at this level, all filtered glucose is completely reabsorbed by the proximal tubule.
  • Option 300 mg/dL: This represents the theoretical threshold calculated by dividing the transport maximum (TmG) by GFR (375 mg/min ÷ 125 mL/min). However, due to nephron heterogeneity (renal splay), the actual threshold is lower.
  • Option 400 mg/dL: This value greatly exceeds both the actual and theoretical renal thresholds for glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The renal threshold for glucose (200 mg/dL) is lower than the theoretical value (300 mg/dL) due to renal splay - the heterogeneity of nephrons in terms of their transport maximum and filtration rates.

questions.text: It is being planned to put posters in the whole city for health promotion. Which type of health education approach is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mass based

 

Posters are a type of mass-based health education approach. Health education approaches can be divided into three main categories:

 

  • Individual-based methods (like interpersonal communication, personal letters, home visits)
  • Group-based methods (like lectures, focus group discussions, panel discussions)
  • Mass-based methods (like posters, television, radio, newsprint, banners, charts)

 

Posters placed throughout a city reach a large audience simultaneously and are therefore classified as a mass-based approach to health education.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Individual based: Incorrect as individual-based approaches involve one-on-one interactions like personal counseling or home visits 

 

Option B. Group-based: Incorrect as group-based approaches involve interactive sessions with specific groups like lectures or workshops 

 

Option D. One to one: Incorrect as this is a form of individual communication and not suitable for city-wide health promotion through posters

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posters are a mass-based health education approach used for reaching large populations simultaneously with health messages.

 

Approaches For Health Communication

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

questions.text: In primary accidental hypothermia, what is the usual rate of rewarming with passive external rewarming?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-2°C per hour

 

Explanation

 

Primary accidental hypothermia refers to an unintentional drop in core body temperature due to environmental exposure. The management of hypothermia includes rewarming strategies, which can be classified into passive and active rewarming.

 

Passive External Rewarming: This method involves insulating the patient by covering them with blankets and ensuring that the head is also covered. It relies on the patient's own heat production to gradually increase body temperature.

 

According to standard medical guidelines and Harrison's principles, passive external rewarming can increase the core body temperature by approximately 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In cases of primary accidental hypothermia, passive external rewarming can raise the core body temperature by 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Additional Information –

 

Hypothermia based on core body temperature and corresponding treatment methods:

 

  1. Mild Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 35 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Passive external rewarming is the treatment of choice.
  2. Moderate Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 32 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.
  3. Severe Hypothermia
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 28 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.

choices.text: Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Put the cord above the vertex

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is in labor. The cervix is 3 cm dilated and 70% effaced. A "bag of worms" is felt. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

 

The description "bag of worms" suggests a cord prolapse, a critical situation where the umbilical cord precedes the fetus, risking compression. An emergency lower segment caesarean section (LSCS) is vital to prevent fetal distress or demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse: Rupturing membranes could worsen cord compression.

 

Option C. Put the cord above the vertex: Attempting to reposition the cord is risky and generally not recommended.

 

Option D. Wait for spontaneous delivery: Waiting is not advisable due to the risk of cord compression and fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected cord prolapse during labor, an emergency LSCS is the recommended course of action to safely deliver the baby and minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Rotavirus Vaccine 

 

Explanation: 

 

The first licensed rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn from the market in 1999 due to an increased risk of intussusception. Intussusception is a condition where one segment of intestine telescopes into another segment, causing intestinal obstruction. The original RotaShield vaccine showed an association with intussusception at a rate of approximately 1 case per 10,000 vaccinated infants, with most cases occurring within 1 week of the first dose. This led to its voluntary withdrawal. Newer rotavirus vaccines (RotaTeq and Rotarix) were subsequently developed and have a much lower risk of intussusception (approximately 1-5 cases per 100,000 vaccinated infants).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) - Incorrect. The MMR vaccine has never been withdrawn from the market. While it has faced controversy due to a now-retracted publication suggesting a link to autism, this claim has been thoroughly disproven by multiple large studies, and MMR remains an essential component of childhood immunization programs.

 

Option C. JE Vaccine (Japanese Encephalitis) - Incorrect. The JE vaccine has not been withdrawn due to intussusception. Some older versions had higher rates of adverse effects, but these were primarily allergic reactions, not intussusception.

 

Option D. Polio Vaccine - Incorrect. The oral polio vaccine (OPV) has been replaced by the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) in many countries, but this was due to the rare risk of vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP), not intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The original rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception.
